note_text:
PATIENT: Robert McNeil
MRN: 700001
DOB: 02/11/1957 (68 years)
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 03/18/2025
LOCATION: Naval Medical Center San Diego – Bronchoscopy Suite

PROCEDURE: Flexible bronchoscopy with linear endobronchial ultrasound–guided transbronchial needle aspiration (EBUS-TBNA) of mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes.
OPERATORS:
  Primary Operator: David Kim, MD – Interventional Pulmonology (Attending)
  Assistant: Maria Lopez, MD – Pulmonary Fellow (PGY-5)
  Bronchoscopy RN: Jonathan Johnson, RN
  RT: Erica White, RRT

INDICATION:
68-year-old male with 3.2 cm left upper lobe mass and PET-avid mediastinal/hilar adenopathy (stations 4R, 4L, 7, 10L) requiring tissue for lung cancer staging and diagnosis.

ANESTHESIA / AIRWAY:
General anesthesia provided by Anesthesia service. Orotracheal intubation with 8.5 mm ETT. Patient positioned supine. Continuous cardiac monitoring, pulse oximetry, NIBP.

PROCEDURE DESCRIPTION:
Time-out was performed confirming patient, procedure, and site. The bronchoscope was advanced through the ETT under direct visualization. Trachea and bilateral bronchial tree were inspected to subsegmental level. No endobronchial tumor, secretions, or active bleeding was seen.

EBUS TECHNIQUE:
The diagnostic scope was exchanged for a convex linear EBUS bronchoscope (Olympus BF-UC180F). Complete systematic nodal survey was performed. Target stations were identified by ultrasound and measured.

STATIONS SAMPLED:
• Station 4R: 1.5 x 1.3 cm oval node, heterogeneous with distinct margins. Three passes with 22G EBUS needle; ROSE adequate with malignant cells.
• Station 4L: 1.2 x 1.0 cm node, mildly enlarged. Three passes with 22G needle; ROSE adequate lymphocytes, no definite malignancy.
• Station 7 (subcarinal): 2.0 x 1.6 cm node, heterogeneous with central necrosis. Four passes; ROSE suspicious for malignancy.
• Station 10L: 1.0 x 0.8 cm node. Two passes; ROSE adequate lymphocytes.

A total of 12 needle passes were performed. Specimens were sent for cytology, cell block, and molecular profiling (EGFR/ALK/ROS1/BRAF, PD-L1) per lung cancer protocol.

COMPLICATIONS:
No significant bleeding, hypoxia, or arrhythmia occurred. Estimated blood loss < 5 mL. No immediate complications were observed.

DISPOSITION / PLAN:
Patient was extubated in the procedure room and transferred to PACU in stable condition on 2 L/min nasal cannula. Planned outpatient follow-up in IP clinic in 1–2 weeks to review final pathology and staging. CT chest with contrast and brain MRI are already scheduled.

PRELIMINARY IMPRESSION:
Successful systematic EBUS-TBNA of mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes (stations 4R, 4L, 7, 10L) for lung cancer staging. ROSE suggests malignant involvement at 4R and 7; final cytology and molecular testing pending.

SIGNED:
David Kim, MD
Interventional Pulmonology

registry_entry.primary_indication: Left upper lobe mass with PET-avid mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy; EBUS-TBNA for lung cancer staging.
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignancy suspected; cytology and molecular testing pending.

evidence.attending_name: Primary Operator: David Kim, MD – Interventional Pulmonology (Attending)
evidence.ebus_stations_sampled: STATIONS SAMPLED: 4R, 4L, 7, 10L described in detail in the EBUS TECHNIQUE section.

registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Adequate - malignant at 4R and 7; benign lymphocytes at 4L and 10L.

changes: Validated CPT codes [31652] against IP_Registry and ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Added coding_review with CPT summary, 2025 facility RVUs/payments, and rationale.

rows.description: Bronchoscopy with EBUS-guided transbronchial sampling, initial mediastinal/hilar station(s).
Bronchoscopy with EBUS-guided sampling, each additional mediastinal/hilar station.

notes: RVUs derived from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 using 2025 facility rate assumptions.
Payments are approximate and do not reflect geographic adjustment, sequestration, or MPPR.

rules_applied.description: Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled when EBUS-guided nodal sampling is performed in the same session.
Moderate sedation codes (99152/+99153) are not reported when a separate anesthesia service provides general anesthesia.

narrative: 31652 is chosen for EBUS-guided sampling of mediastinal/hilar nodes including the initial station.
31653 is added to account for sampling additional nodal stations beyond the initial site.
No separate diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is billed because inspection is inherent to EBUS bronchoscopy.
Moderate sedation codes are not reported because anesthesia provided general anesthesia via ETT.

31653.rationale: EBUS-TBNA of 4 nodal stations (4R, 4L, 7, 10L) supports the 3+ station code 31653. 31652 (1-2 stations) is incorrect.

note_level_rationale: Systematic EBUS-TBNA staging of 4 stations supports 31653.

note_text:
Name: Angela Rivera
MRN: 700002
DOB: 06/04/1965 (59 years)
Date of Service: 04/09/2025
Location: Bronchoscopy/Procedural Suite

Procedure: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS confirmation and transbronchial biopsies of peripheral RUL nodule.
Operating Physician: Michael Thompson, MD (Interventional Pulmonology)
Assistant: Brian Wu, MD (Pulmonary Fellow)
RT: Sarah Long, RRT
RN: Casey Nguyen, RN

Indication:
59-year-old female with 8 mm posterior segment right upper lobe nodule, intensely PET-avid, bronchus sign positive on CT, no clear mediastinal adenopathy. Referred for minimally invasive diagnostic biopsy.

Anesthesia/Airway:
General anesthesia with LMA provided by Anesthesia team. Patient in supine position. Standard ASA monitors in place.

Procedure Description:
Following time-out, the robotic bronchoscopy platform was docked (Monarch system). Pre-procedure CT was loaded and registration performed using automatic airway mapping with final registration error < 2 mm.

Using the navigation interface, the robotic scope was advanced to the posterior segment of the RUL following the virtual pathway. The working channel was aligned to the target; divergence from the target center was < 3 mm.

Radial EBUS:
A radial EBUS probe with guide sheath was advanced through the working channel. A concentric, solid lesion was visualized corresponding to the CT target. The guide sheath was left in place at the point of maximal signal.

Sampling:
Through the guide sheath, the following samples were obtained:
• Transbronchial forceps biopsies: 6 passes from the RUL posterior segment nodule.
• Transbronchial needle aspiration: 3 passes with a 21G needle targeting the same lesion.
• Cytology brushings: 2 passes from the nodule.

All samples were sent for histology, cytology, microbiology, and molecular profiling including PD-L1. No significant bleeding occurred; minor oozing resolved with wedging and suction.

Complications:
No hypoxia, arrhythmia, or pneumothorax was observed. Fluoroscopy was used intermittently to confirm tool position. Estimated blood loss < 5 mL.

Disposition/Plan:
Patient was extubated and transported to PACU in stable condition. Post-procedure CXR to evaluate for pneumothorax was ordered. Follow-up visit in IP clinic in 1–2 weeks to discuss results and management options.

Impression:
Successful robotic navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS confirmation and transbronchial sampling of an 8 mm RUL posterior segment nodule. Final pathology pending.

registry_entry.primary_indication: PET-avid 8 mm posterior segment RUL nodule with positive bronchus sign; navigational bronchoscopy for diagnosis.
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Peripheral lung nodule; malignancy vs infection – pathology pending.

evidence.navigation: Robotic navigational bronchoscopy with Monarch system; registration error < 2 mm.
evidence.radial_ebus: Radial EBUS with concentric view confirming the RUL posterior segment lesion.
evidence.sampling: Transbronchial forceps biopsies (6), TBNA (3), and brushings (2) from the targeted nodule.

changes: Validated CPT codes [31653] against IP_Registry and ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Added coding_review with CPT summary, 2025 facility RVUs/payments, and rationale.

rows.description: Bronchoscopy with computer-assisted/navigational guidance to a peripheral lesion.
Bronchoscopy with radial EBUS for peripheral lesion localization.
Bronchoscopy with transbronchial lung biopsy, single lobe.

notes: RVUs taken from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 bronchoscopy navigation and peripheral biopsy tables.
Radial EBUS (31654) is treated as an add-on code for peripheral lesion work-up.

rules_applied.description: Radial EBUS (31654) should only be reported when accompanied by transbronchial biopsy (31628) or TBNA.
Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) and simple TBLB (31623) are not separately reported when more advanced sampling (31627/31628/31654) is performed.
Moderate sedation code 99152 is not billed when anesthesia provides general anesthesia.

narrative: 31627 is selected for computer-assisted/robotic navigation to the peripheral RUL nodule.
31654 is appropriate because radial EBUS was explicitly used to localize the lesion prior to sampling.
31628 captures the transbronchial forceps lung biopsies in the targeted RUL posterior segment.
Diagnostic bronchoscopy and simple TBLB codes are not separately billed, and moderate sedation code 99152 is not reported because anesthesia administered general anesthesia.

31629.rationale: Transbronchial needle aspiration (3 passes) of the peripheral nodule.

31628.rationale: Transbronchial forceps biopsy (6 passes) of the same nodule.

31654.rationale: Radial EBUS for peripheral lesion confirmation.

note_level_rationale: Added 31629 (TBNA) and 31623 (Brush) as they were documented in the note but missing from the registry extraction.
Robotic navigation (31627) and radial EBUS (31654) are appropriate add-ons.

note_text:
PATIENT: James Caldwell
MRN: 700003
DOB: 01/22/1952 (73 years)
DATE: 05/01/2025
LOCATION: Main OR – Hybrid Suite

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Severe mid-tracheal obstruction from squamous cell carcinoma.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same.

PROCEDURE:
1. Rigid therapeutic bronchoscopy with destruction of endobronchial tumor.
2. Flexible bronchoscopy.
3. Tracheal silicone stent placement.

SURGEON: Laura Bennett, MD (Interventional Pulmonology)
ASSISTANT: Andrew Park, MD (Thoracic Surgery Fellow)
ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscopy and jet ventilation.

INDICATION:
73-year-old male with known squamous cell carcinoma of the mid-trachea, presenting with stridor and 80% luminal obstruction on CT and bronchoscopy. Planned rigid therapeutic bronchoscopy with debulking and airway stent placement for palliation and airway stabilization.

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
After induction of general anesthesia, a rigid tracheobronchoscope was introduced under direct visualization. Tumor causing near circumferential narrowing of the mid-trachea over ~3 cm was identified.

Tumor Debulking:
Mechanical debulking was performed using the bevel of the rigid scope and large forceps to core out the intraluminal mass. Argon plasma coagulation (APC) at 35 W and 1.5 L/min flow was then applied circumferentially to residual tumor and bleeding points until a widely patent lumen was obtained. Approximate residual obstruction was < 20% with smooth mucosal surface.

Stent Placement:
A 16 x 50 mm straight silicone Dumon stent was selected. Under direct bronchoscopic visualization, the stent was mounted on the rigid stent loader and deployed across the involved segment. Final position covered the entire tumor bed with adequate proximal and distal margins. The stent was well seated with no migration and good distal ventilation.

The airway was reinspected distally with a flexible bronchoscope through the rigid barrel. No additional endobronchial disease was identified. Secretions were suctioned.

COMPLICATIONS:
Total estimated blood loss ~20 mL. No significant hypoxia, arrhythmia, or airway perforation. No intraoperative complications.

DISPOSITION:
The rigid scope was removed and the patient was transitioned back to a standard ETT and subsequently extubated in the OR. He was transported to PACU on 4 L/min nasal cannula in stable condition. Follow-up CT and bronchoscopy are planned in 4–6 weeks.

IMPRESSION:
Successful rigid therapeutic bronchoscopy with tumor destruction and silicone tracheal stent placement for malignant tracheal obstruction, with marked improvement in airway patency.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Severe malignant mid-tracheal obstruction from squamous cell carcinoma causing near-critical airway compromise.
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant central airway obstruction due to tracheal squamous cell carcinoma.

evidence.tumor_destruction: Mechanical debulking plus APC applied to residual tumor in the mid-trachea.
evidence.stent: 16 x 50 mm straight silicone Dumon stent placed across the mid-tracheal tumor bed.

registry_entry.institution_name: Hybrid OR – Tertiary Military Medical Center

changes: Validated CPT codes [31627, 31654, 31628, 31652] against IP_Registry and ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Added coding_review with CPT summary, 2025 facility RVUs/payments, and rationale for combined navigation, radial EBUS, TBLB, and nodal staging.

rows.description: Bronchoscopy with destruction of endobronchial tumor or relief of stenosis by any method.
Bronchoscopy with placement of bronchial or tracheal stent, initial bronchus or tracheal segment.

notes: RVUs drawn from bronchoscopy therapeutic airway and stent tables in ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Values approximate 2025 Medicare facility payments assuming a standard conversion factor.

rules_applied.description: Diagnostic bronchoscopy is bundled when significant therapeutic airway procedures are performed in the same session.
Balloon dilation (31630) used solely to facilitate stent placement in the same segment is not separately billed.
Moderate sedation is not reported when general anesthesia is provided by a separate anesthesia service.

narrative: 31641 is appropriate because significant tumor destruction and debulking were performed with rigid coring and APC.
31636 is selected for placement of a silicone tracheal stent in the mid-trachea across the malignant obstruction.
No separate diagnostic or dilation code is billed because inspection and dilation are integral to the therapeutic procedure.
Moderate sedation is not coded due to the use of general anesthesia with rigid bronchoscopy.

note_level_rationale: Therapeutic rigid bronchoscopy with tumor destruction (31641) and stent placement (31636).

note_text:
PATIENT: Matthew Li
MRN: 700004
AGE: 56 years
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 02/20/2025
LOCATION: ICU Bedside

PRE-OP DIAGNOSIS: Right parapneumonic effusion with suspected empyema.
POST-OP DIAGNOSIS: Same.

PROCEDURES:
1. Ultrasound-guided diagnostic and therapeutic right thoracentesis.
2. Insertion of right large-bore chest tube for ongoing drainage.

OPERATOR: Emily Rogers, MD (Pulmonary/Critical Care)
ASSISTANT: ICU Resident PGY-2

INDICATION:
56-year-old male with severe community-acquired pneumonia and enlarging right pleural effusion with loculations and fevers despite antibiotics. Ultrasound reveals complex septated effusion. Bedside thoracentesis for diagnosis followed by chest tube for continued drainage.

ULTRASOUND-GUIDED THORACENTESIS:
The patient was positioned sitting upright. Right posterolateral chest was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Ultrasound identified a moderate, complex right pleural effusion with diaphragmatic excursion and no obvious lung entrapment. A safe window in the right posterior axillary line at the 8th intercostal space was chosen.

Local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine was infiltrated down to the pleura. A 19G needle with catheter was advanced above the rib under real-time ultrasound guidance into the pleural space with return of turbid, yellow fluid. Approximately 40 mL of fluid was aspirated for diagnostic studies (chemistry, cell count, Gram stain/culture, cytology, pH, LDH, glucose).

CHEST TUBE INSERTION:
Given the thick, loculated nature of the effusion and sepsis, a decision was made to place a large-bore chest tube. A 28 Fr straight chest tube was inserted via a separate incision at the mid-axillary line in the 6th intercostal space using blunt dissection and Seldinger technique into the posterolateral collection. The tube was secured with sutures and connected to -20 cm H2O suction.

Initial drainage was approximately 900 mL of turbid, malodorous fluid. The patient tolerated the procedure without hypotension or significant desaturation. Post-procedure ultrasound confirmed lung expansion, and a CXR was ordered to confirm position and evaluate for complications.

COMPLICATIONS:
No immediate pneumothorax, bleeding, or organ injury was observed.

DISPOSITION:
Patient remained in the ICU on existing vasopressor and ventilator settings. Plan for intrapleural fibrinolytics if imaging shows persistent loculations.

IMPRESSION:
Successful ultrasound-guided right thoracentesis with large-volume purulent fluid removal and placement of a large-bore right chest tube for ongoing drainage of presumed empyema.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Right complex parapneumonic effusion/empyema requiring diagnostic sampling and therapeutic drainage.

evidence.thoracentesis: Ultrasound-guided diagnostic and therapeutic right thoracentesis via 8th intercostal space.
evidence.tube_thoracostomy: 28 Fr straight chest tube placed in right mid-axillary line with immediate drainage of purulent fluid.

changes: Validated CPT codes [31624] against IP_Registry and ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Clarified that EBUS-TBNA was aborted without nodal sampling and added coding_review with RVUs for 31624.

rows.description: Thoracentesis, diagnostic or therapeutic; with imaging guidance (e.g., ultrasound).
Tube thoracostomy with insertion of chest tube for drainage.

notes: RVUs derived from pleural procedure tables in ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Thoracentesis and chest tube placement are separately billable when both are clearly documented and clinically necessary.

rules_applied.description: When ultrasound guidance is documented, 32555 is preferred over 32554.
Chest tube insertion (32551) is separately reportable when performed for ongoing drainage after diagnostic thoracentesis.

narrative: 32555 is selected because thoracentesis was performed with real-time ultrasound guidance and both diagnostic and therapeutic intent.
32551 is separately reported for placement of a large-bore 28 Fr chest tube for ongoing drainage of empyema.
Standalone non-image-guided thoracentesis code 32554 is not used since ultrasound guidance was explicitly documented.

note_level_rationale: Both thoracentesis (32555) and chest tube placement (32551) are supported as they were distinct procedures (sampling then large-bore tube placement).

note_text:
PATIENT: Lucille Brown
MRN: 700005
DOB: 09/30/1942 (82 years)
DATE: 01/14/2025
LOCATION: Outpatient Procedure Room

PROCEDURE: Bedside diagnostic and therapeutic left thoracentesis without imaging guidance.
PHYSICIAN: Hannah Patel, MD

INDICATION:
82-year-old female with chronic systolic heart failure (EF 25%), progressive dyspnea, and large left pleural effusion on chest radiograph. No ultrasound available in the clinic procedure room. Thoracentesis was requested for symptomatic relief and to confirm a transudative effusion.

PROCEDURE DESCRIPTION:
The patient was seated upright, leaning forward over a bedside table. Left posterior hemithorax was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Percussion and auscultation identified a level of dullness consistent with a moderate free-flowing effusion.

Local anesthesia was achieved with 1% lidocaine infiltrated into skin, subcutaneous tissue, and intercostal muscles at the left posterior 8th intercostal space in the mid-scapular line. Using landmark technique, an 18G over-the-needle catheter was advanced just superior to the rib into the pleural space with immediate return of straw-colored fluid.

Approximately 60 mL of fluid was aspirated into syringes and sent for chemistry (protein, LDH), cell count/differential, Gram stain/culture, and cytology. An additional 900 mL was drained slowly by gravity with the patient monitored for cough, chest discomfort, or hypotension. The catheter was then removed and a sterile dressing applied.

COMPLICATIONS:
The patient experienced mild coughing toward the end of the drainage but no significant pleuritic pain or hypotension. No immediate pneumothorax was evident clinically. Post-procedure CXR was ordered.

DISPOSITION:
The patient remained in the clinic for a brief observation period and was then discharged home with instructions to return for worsening dyspnea. Outpatient follow-up with cardiology and pulmonary clinic is arranged.

IMPRESSION:
Landmark-guided diagnostic and therapeutic left thoracentesis for presumed heart failure-related effusion; fluid characteristics pending.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Large symptomatic left pleural effusion in a patient with advanced systolic heart failure.
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Likely transudative pleural effusion due to heart failure; pleural fluid studies pending.

evidence.volume: Approximately 900 mL additional fluid drained after diagnostic sampling.

changes: Validated CPT codes [31645] against IP_Registry and ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Confirmed this was routine stent maintenance without repositioning or exchange and added coding_review with RVUs for 31645.

rows.description: Thoracentesis, diagnostic or therapeutic; without imaging guidance.

notes: Code 32554 is used when thoracentesis is performed without imaging guidance.
RVUs derived from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 pleural tables for facility setting.

rules_applied.description: Use 32554 when no ultrasound or other imaging guidance is documented.

narrative: The note explicitly states landmark-guided thoracentesis with no ultrasound available, so 32554 is appropriate.
Ultrasound-guided thoracentesis code 32555 is not billed.

note_text:
PATIENT: Samuel Patel
MRN: 700006
AGE: 69 years
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 03/05/2025
LOCATION: Pleural Procedure Suite

PRE-PROCEDURE DIAGNOSIS: Recurrent right malignant pleural effusion secondary to metastatic lung adenocarcinoma.
POST-PROCEDURE DIAGNOSIS: Same.

PROCEDURE: Ultrasound-guided tunneled indwelling pleural catheter placement (PleurX) with large-volume drainage.

PHYSICIAN: Rachel Green, MD (Interventional Pulmonology)
ASSISTANT: Pulmonary Fellow PGY-6

INDICATION:
69-year-old male with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma and recurrent symptomatic right pleural effusion requiring thoracentesis every 7–10 days. Shared decision-making favored tunneled indwelling pleural catheter placement for symptom control and outpatient management.

PROCEDURE DESCRIPTION:
Pre-procedure ultrasound confirmed a large free-flowing right pleural effusion with no significant loculations. Patient was positioned supine with head of bed elevated.

After time-out, the right lateral chest wall was prepped and draped. Local anesthesia was obtained with 1% lidocaine at the planned entry and exit sites. Under real-time ultrasound guidance, an 18G finder needle was advanced into the pleural space at the right mid-axillary line, 6th intercostal space, with return of serosanguinous fluid.

A guidewire was advanced and serial dilation performed. A subcutaneous tunnel approximately 7 cm in length was created anteriorly, and the PleurX catheter was pulled through the tunnel exiting at the anterior chest wall. The peel-away sheath was then advanced into the pleural space over the guidewire, and the catheter was inserted and the sheath removed.

The catheter was connected to a vacuum drainage bottle; approximately 1,500 mL of serosanguinous fluid was drained slowly with monitoring for chest discomfort and blood pressure changes. The catheter tip position was confirmed by ultrasound. The exit site and entry site were secured with sutures and sterile dressings.

COMPLICATIONS:
No significant pain, hypotension, or re-expansion pulmonary edema occurred. No immediate bleeding or air leak was noted.

DISPOSITION:
The patient was discharged home the same day with home health nursing arranged for drainage three times per week and instructions for signs of infection or catheter malfunction.

IMPRESSION:
Technically successful ultrasound-guided placement of a tunneled right PleurX catheter with large-volume drainage of recurrent malignant effusion.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent symptomatic right malignant pleural effusion requiring tunneled catheter for outpatient drainage.
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant pleural effusion due to metastatic lung adenocarcinoma.

evidence.ipc: Tunneled PleurX catheter placed via subcutaneous tunnel with peel-away sheath technique.
evidence.volume: Approximately 1,500 mL of serosanguinous fluid drained at the time of placement.
evidence.side: Right hemithorax described repeatedly as site of effusion and catheter placement.

changes: Validated CPT codes [31631] against IP_Registry and ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Confirmed balloon dilation occurred only in the stented segment and added coding_review with RVUs for 31631.

rows.description: Insertion of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter with cuff (e.g., PleurX).

notes: RVUs taken from tunneled pleural catheter placement tables in ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Drainage at time of placement is considered integral to code 32550 and not separately billed.

rules_applied.description: Standalone thoracentesis is not reported separately when performed as part of tunneled pleural catheter placement.

narrative: 32550 captures both the tunneled pleural catheter insertion and associated drainage at the time of placement.
No separate thoracentesis code (32555) is billed because fluid removal is integral to the IPC placement service.

32550.rationale: Insertion of tunneled indwelling pleural catheter.

note_level_rationale: Tunneled catheter placement (32550) is the correct code.

note_text:
PATIENT: Diane Curry
MRN: 700007
AGE: 64 years
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 06/02/2025
LOCATION: Outpatient Procedure Room

PRE-PROCEDURE DIAGNOSIS: Right malignant pleural effusion status post tunneled pleural catheter with clinical autopleurodesis.
POST-PROCEDURE DIAGNOSIS: Same.

PROCEDURE: Removal of tunneled indwelling pleural catheter.

PHYSICIAN: Thomas Nguyen, MD (Interventional Pulmonology)

INDICATION:
64-year-old female with metastatic breast cancer and right malignant pleural effusion managed with a PleurX catheter placed 7 months ago. She has had no drainage for 6 weeks and imaging shows a small residual effusion with lung expansion, consistent with spontaneous pleurodesis. The catheter site is mildly irritated and the patient wishes to have it removed.

PROCEDURE DESCRIPTION:
The patient was placed in the supine position. The right lateral chest and catheter exit site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthesia was provided with 1% lidocaine infiltrated around the cuff and exit site.

The tunnel tract and cuff were gently dissected free using a small scalpel and blunt dissection. Once the cuff was fully mobilized, steady traction was applied and the PleurX catheter was removed intact without resistance. The tunnel was probed digitally to confirm no retained cuff material.

Hemostasis was achieved with gauze and direct pressure. The exit site was closed with a single 3-0 nylon suture and covered with a sterile dressing.

COMPLICATIONS:
Minimal bleeding, no pneumothorax, no air leak. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

DISPOSITION:
The patient was observed for 30 minutes and discharged home in stable condition with instructions for wound care and removal of sutures in 7–10 days.

IMPRESSION:
Uncomplicated removal of tunneled right pleural catheter after successful autopleurodesis.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Clinically nonfunctional tunneled pleural catheter after presumed autopleurodesis for malignant effusion.
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Resolved malignant effusion with catheter-related skin irritation.

evidence.ipc_removal: Description of cuff dissection and catheter removal intact.
evidence.side: Right lateral chest described as catheter exit site.

changes: Validated CPT codes [31641] against IP_Registry and ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Clarified ablation-only tumor destruction without excision and added coding_review with RVUs for 31641.

rows.description: Removal of tunneled indwelling pleural catheter.

notes: Code 32552 represents removal of a tunneled indwelling pleural catheter and does not include new catheter insertion.
RVUs derived from tunneled catheter removal section in ip_coding_billing.v2_7.

narrative: The only billable service is removal of the existing tunneled pleural catheter; no drainage or new catheter placement is documented.
32552 appropriately captures this service.

32552.rationale: Removal of tunneled indwelling pleural catheter.

note_text:
PATIENT: Miguel Sanchez
MRN: 700008
AGE: 49 years
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 07/11/2025
LOCATION: Interventional Radiology/Pleural Suite

PRE-PROCEDURE DIAGNOSIS: Loculated right malignant pleural effusion, not amenable to simple thoracentesis.
POST-PROCEDURE DIAGNOSIS: Same.

PROCEDURE: Ultrasound-guided placement of small-bore pleural drainage catheter (pigtail) for malignant effusion.

PHYSICIAN: Olivia Harris, MD (Interventional Pulmonology)

INDICATION:
49-year-old male with metastatic renal cell carcinoma and recurrent right pleural effusion. Prior thoracenteses provided temporary relief; current ultrasound demonstrates loculated collections along the posterolateral chest wall. Decision made to place a small-bore pigtail catheter for ongoing drainage.

PROCEDURE DESCRIPTION:
With the patient in the left lateral decubitus position, a comprehensive ultrasound exam localized a large posterolateral fluid pocket without diaphragmatic or lung adhesions. Skin was marked in the mid-axillary line at the level of the 7th intercostal space.

After sterile prep and drape, local anesthesia was obtained with 1% lidocaine. Under real-time ultrasound guidance, an 18G needle was advanced into the collection with return of blood-tinged serous fluid. A 0.035" guidewire was passed and the tract was dilated.

A 12 Fr pigtail catheter was advanced over the wire into the pleural space and the pigtail was formed. The catheter was attached to a closed drainage system and secured with suture and anchoring device.

Approximately 700 mL of serosanguinous fluid drained during the procedure. The patient tolerated the procedure well.

COMPLICATIONS:
No evidence of pneumothorax or bleeding on immediate post-procedure ultrasound. Estimated blood loss < 10 mL.

DISPOSITION:
Patient returned to the oncology floor with the catheter to continuous drainage and plan for daily monitoring of output and consideration of talc slurry pleurodesis if lung remains expandable.

IMPRESSION:
Successful ultrasound-guided placement of a right pleural pigtail catheter (12 Fr) for ongoing drainage of malignant effusion.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent loculated right malignant pleural effusion requiring indwelling small-bore drainage catheter.
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant pleural effusion due to metastatic renal cell carcinoma.

evidence.catheter: 12 Fr pigtail catheter placed into right pleural space under real-time ultrasound guidance.
evidence.side: Right pleural space described throughout the procedure.

changes: Validated CPT codes [31634] against IP_Registry and ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Confirmed focus on hemorrhage control without biopsy/navigation and added coding_review with RVUs for 31634.

rows.description: Placement of percutaneous small-bore pleural drainage catheter with imaging guidance.

notes: Code 32557 is used for ultrasound-guided placement of a small-bore pleural drainage catheter (pigtail).
RVUs and payment estimates are derived from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 pleural drainage catheter schedules.

rules_applied.description: When a drainage catheter is placed, a separate thoracentesis code is generally not reported for the same effusion.
Non-tunneled pigtail catheter placement is coded with 32557 rather than tunneled catheter code 32550.

narrative: Procedure documentation supports image-guided placement of a small-bore pleural drainage catheter, which is best captured by 32557.
Thoracentesis and tunneled catheter codes are not separately reported for this encounter.

32557.rationale: Placement of small-bore pleural catheter with imaging guidance.

note_text:
PATIENT: Linda Ngo
MRN: 700009
DOB: 10/09/1953 (71 years)
DATE OF SERVICE: 08/19/2025
LOCATION: Bronchoscopy Suite

PROCEDURES:
1. Flexible bronchoscopy with linear EBUS-TBNA of mediastinal/hilar lymph nodes.
2. Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy to right lower lobe lesion.
3. Transbronchial lung biopsies of right lower lobe lesion.

OPERATOR: Jason Miller, MD (Interventional Pulmonology)
FELLOW: Priya Shah, MD (PGY-6)

INDICATION:
71-year-old female with a 2.5 cm right lower lobe mass and enlarged PET-avid subcarinal and right paratracheal nodes. Referred for combined mediastinal staging and bronchoscopic diagnosis of the parenchymal lesion.

ANESTHESIA/AIRWAY:
General anesthesia with ETT. Patient in supine position.

EBUS-TBNA:
A convex probe EBUS bronchoscope was used for systematic mediastinal staging. Nodes were identified and sampled as follows:
• Station 4R: 1.4 cm, oval; 3 passes with 22G needle.
• Station 7: 2.0 cm, heterogeneous; 4 passes with 22G needle.
• Station 11R: 1.1 cm; 3 passes with 22G needle.
ROSE was adequate at all stations, with malignant cells seen at 4R and 7.

NAVIGATIONAL BRONCHOSCOPY/TBLB:
After completing EBUS, an electromagnetic navigation system (superDimension) was used. The pre-procedure CT was registered and the right lower lobe lesion target planned. Navigation error was approximately 2.5 mm.

A thin bronchoscope was advanced along the projected path to a subsegmental bronchus in the basilar segment of the RLL. The target lesion was reached and confirmed by fluoroscopy. Multiple transbronchial biopsies (5 forceps samples) and cytology brushings (2) were obtained from the lesion.

COMPLICATIONS:
Minor bleeding controlled with cold saline and suction. No significant hypoxia or pneumothorax observed. Estimated blood loss < 10 mL.

DISPOSITION:
The patient was extubated and transferred to PACU in stable condition, with a post-procedure CXR ordered. She will follow up in IP clinic in 1–2 weeks.

IMPRESSION:
Combined EBUS-TBNA of 4R, 7, and 11R nodes and navigational bronchoscopy with fluoroscopic confirmation and transbronchial biopsies of an RLL mass.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Right lower lobe lung mass with PET-avid mediastinal/hilar lymphadenopathy; combined staging and diagnosis.
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant adenopathy at 4R/7; parenchymal biopsy pending.

evidence.ebus: EBUS-TBNA of stations 4R, 7, and 11R with malignant cells at 4R and 7 on ROSE.
evidence.navigation: Electromagnetic navigation with superDimension system to RLL lesion.
evidence.tblb: Five transbronchial biopsies obtained from the RLL mass.

registry_entry.ebus_rose_result: Adequate - malignant at 4R and 7; benign lymphocytes at 11R.

Clarified pleurodesis via existing catheter without new tunneled catheter and added coding_review with RVUs for 32560.

rules_applied.description: Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) and basic TBLB (31623) are bundled when more advanced EBUS and navigational sampling is performed.
Radial EBUS (31654) is not reported here because it is not documented; only EM navigation and fluoroscopy were used.
Moderate sedation codes 99152/+99153 are not billed when general anesthesia is provided by anesthesia service.

narrative: 31652 is selected for initial EBUS-TBNA stations (4R, 7, 11R) with malignant ROSE at 4R and 7.
31653 is appended for sampling additional nodal stations beyond the first.
31627 and 31628 capture EM navigation and transbronchial lung biopsies of the RLL mass.
No separate diagnostic bronchoscopy or basic TBLB codes are billed, and moderate sedation codes are excluded due to use of general anesthesia.

note_level_rationale: EBUS of 3 stations (4R, 7, 11R) maps to 31653. 31652 (1-2 stations) was removed.

note_text:
PATIENT: Omar Rahman
MRN: 700010
DOB: 12/03/1960 (64 years)
DATE OF SERVICE: 09/22/2025
LOCATION: Bronchoscopy Suite

PROCEDURES:
1. Flexible bronchoscopy with transbronchial lung biopsy (TBLB), left lower lobe.
2. Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy to left lower lobe lesion.
3. Linear EBUS-TBNA of station 7.

OPERATOR: Karen Lee, MD (Interventional Pulmonology)

INDICATION:
64-year-old male with a 2.0 cm left lower lobe superior segment nodule and mildly enlarged subcarinal lymph node (station 7). PET shows moderate uptake in both sites. Combined nodal and parenchymal sampling requested.

PROCEDURE SUMMARY:
Under general anesthesia via ETT, a flexible bronchoscope was passed to the segmental bronchi. No endobronchial tumor was seen.

EBUS-TBNA (station 7):
A convex EBUS scope was used to sample a 1.4 cm subcarinal node. Three passes were performed with a 22G needle. ROSE was adequate with benign-appearing lymphocytes.

EM NAVIGATION + TBLB (LLL superior segment):
An EM navigation system was used to register the pre-procedure CT. The lesion in the LLL superior segment was targeted; registration error ~3 mm. The scope was advanced to the LLL superior segment, and navigation confirmed proximity to the lesion. Fluoroscopy confirmed the biopsy forceps at the lesion margin. Four transbronchial biopsies were obtained; specimens were sent for histology and molecular studies.

No significant bleeding or hypoxia occurred. The patient was extubated and transferred to PACU in stable condition.

IMPRESSION:
Combined EM-navigated transbronchial biopsies of LLL lesion and single-station EBUS-TBNA of station 7 for staging.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Left lower lobe nodule with PET-avid subcarinal lymph node; diagnostic and staging bronchoscopy.
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: EBUS node negative on ROSE; parenchymal biopsy pending.

evidence.ebus: Linear EBUS-TBNA of station 7 with benign lymphocytes on ROSE.
evidence.navigation: EM navigation used to target LLL superior segment lesion with ~3 mm error.
evidence.tblb: Four transbronchial biopsies of the LLL lesion obtained under fluoroscopic guidance.

changes: Validated CPT codes [32555] against IP_Registry and ip_coding_billing.v2_7.
Confirmed ultrasound-guided diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis and added coding_review with RVUs for 32555.

notes: Financial summary reflects combined EBUS, navigation, and transbronchial biopsy services.

rules_applied.description: Only 31652 is billed for a single EBUS station; 31653 is reserved for additional stations.
Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled when EBUS and advanced sampling are performed.
Moderate sedation code 99152 is not reported when general anesthesia is provided by anesthesia service.

narrative: 31652 is reported for EBUS-TBNA of a single subcarinal node (station 7).
31627 and 31628 reflect EM navigation and transbronchial biopsies of the LLL lesion.
31623 may be used in some practices to represent basic TBLB; here it is retained to reflect a mixed documentation style in the source note.
No additional EBUS add-on code or diagnostic bronchoscopy code is billed.

note_level_rationale: Removed 31623 (Brush) as it was not documented in the procedure summary for this specific note.
